channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Liberal Mark Carney projected to remain as Canada's prime minister
item.description: The result, projected by the country’s public broadcaster, was a stunning reversal in fortunes for the Liberal Party, fueled in part by President Donald Trump’s attacks on Canada. Carney, a former central banker, pitched himself as best placed to handle Trump’s trade war, annexation threats and the profound rupture in U.S.-Canada relations.

item.title: FBI, national security agencies are using polygraph tests to search for ‘leakers’
item.description: Current and former officials say the crackdown is creating a climate of fear that goes beyond prior leak investigations and harms national security.

item.title: Lawyers leave Justice Department civil rights office en masse as new leaders shift priorities
item.description: New civil rights division chief Harmeet Dhillon told a conservative podcaster more than 100 attorneys have left their jobs, in many cases because they disagreed with the office’s new focus on combating anti-Christian bias, transgender athletes in women’s sports, antisemitism and “woke ideology.”

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Ghosts of elite-college ambition haunt parent of accomplished teen
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Ghosts of elite-college ambition haunt parent of accomplished teen

item.title: Rep. Gerry Connolly (D-Virginia) announces he will not seek reelection because of cancer resurgence
item.description: Connolly, elected to his Northern Virginia seat in 2008, was first diagnosed with esophageal cancer in November.

item.title: D.C. and Commanders announce $3.7 billion deal to transform RFK Stadium site into a new home for the NFL team
item.description: The Washington Commanders would put up $2.7 billion for the roofed stadium, while total taxpayer costs are expected to top $1 billion — a price tag likely to spur heated debate on the D.C. Council and among residents about how public money is used. The council still needs to approve the deal.

item.title: These red-eyed bugs are singing in today’s On The Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Conclave to select new pope, the largest such gathering in the history of the Catholic Church, will begin May 7, Vatican announces
item.description: The announcement, a week after the death of Pope Francis, sets up the most unpredictable selection process in decades, with several strong contenders emerging, but no clear front-runner.

item.title: Elon Musk. Child removals. Vancouver attack. North Korea. ‘60 Minutes.’ Neck pain. Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: D.C., Commanders plan to announce deal for new stadium at RFK on Monday
item.description: The deal, which must be approved by the D.C. Council, would bring the team back to the city where it last played in 1996. D.C. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser (D) and Commanders principal owner Josh Harris are set to announce details Monday, according to a person familiar with the plan.

item.title: Which cities have the most trees? See how yours stacks up.
item.description: A Washington Post analysis shows how climate and population influence tree cover. Find out which places are growing their urban forest and how your area compares.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Eat it or toss it? Test your food safety knowledge with this quiz.
item.description: Moldy cheese. Old yogurt. That pot of soup you left on the counter overnight. Your appetite for reducing food waste just might be tied to your risk tolerance. Take our quiz to see where you land.

item.title: Trump’s approval rating sinks as Americans criticize his major policies, Post-ABC-Ipsos finds
item.description: As he nears his 100th day in office, President Donald Trump is facing growing opposition to his ambitious and controversial agenda and perceptions that his administration is seeking to avoid complying with federal court orders, according to a Washington Post-ABC News-Ipsos poll.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: At least 9 people killed after vehicle plows through crowd at Vancouver festival for Filipino community
item.description: Police said the “mass casualty incident” took place during the Lapu Lapu Day festival. Police arrested a 30-year-old man at the scene and said they are not treating the incident as an act of terrorism.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: ‘If I don’t do it, nothing gets done.’ My husband says deal with it.
item.description: Ask Sahaj: ‘If I don’t do it, nothing gets done.’ My husband says deal with it.

item.title: Colorado quarterback Shedeur Sanders selected by Cleveland Browns in the fifth round of the NFL draft, ending a multi-day slide
item.description: Sanders was projected to be picked as high as the top five of the first round, yet slipped to the draft’s third day before he was taken. The son of Hall of Fame cornerback and Colorado Coach Deion Sanders, Shedeur Sanders’s fall became the primary storyline of this year’s draft.

item.title: At 77, she’s as fit as a 25-year-old. Here’s what her body tells us about aging.
item.description: Researchers are studying runner Jeannie Rice, who has “outstanding” fitness, to learn how we can stay healthy as we age. She proves “it’s never too late to start exercising,” one scientist said.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: As the Catholic Church lays Pope Francis to rest, tens of thousands are paying respects at funeral, procession
item.description: The solemn proceedings began under crystalline skies, in the shadow of St. Peter’s Basilica, with a requiem Mass. The guests of honor were monarchs, presidents and cardinals. Migrants, prisoners, indigent and transgender faithful are expected at the burial site to celebrate the “people's pope.”

item.title: Virginia Giuffre dies at 41. She was the public face of women who said they were sexually abused and trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein.
item.description: In court papers, lawsuits and interviews spanning nearly a decade, Giuffre recounted coming under Epstein’s control as a 16-year-old and being “passed around like a platter of fruit” to his influential friends, including Britain's Prince Andrew.

item.title: Former congressman George Santos sentenced to more than 7 years in prison after pleading guilty to financial misconduct
item.description: Santos’s attorneys had asked for him to face two years in prison, saying that he had accepted responsibility for his actions and writing in court filings that his actions “stemmed largely from a misguided desperation related to his political campaign, rather than inherent malice.”

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: We were on a date. And then his estranged wife showed up.
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: We were on a date. And then his estranged wife showed up.

item.title: FBI director says Wisconsin judge has been arrested, accused of shielding an immigrant in her courthouse from being detained by ICE
item.description: The arrest of Milwaukee County Circuit Judge Hannah Dugan was announced on X by FBI Director Kash Patel. The tweet was later deleted. It would be the first publicly known instance of the Justice Department charging a local official with allegedly interfering with immigration enforcement since President Donald Trump returned to the White House.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Analysis: A baby-faced GM swooped in for Travis Hunter and rocked the NFL draft. Here’s what we learned in the first round.
item.description: As the NFL draft began Thursday night, the Jacksonville Jaguars executed one of the boldest trades in draft history to secure the Heisman Trophy winner, the Cleveland Browns gave themselves multiple options to draft a quarterback, and the New York Giants traded up for Mississippi quarterback Jaxson Dart, leaving Colorado’s Shedeur Sanders still available at the close of a fascinating night.

item.title: Majority of Americans now disapprove of Trump’s handling of immigration, a change from earlier this year, Post-ABC-Ipsos poll finds
item.description: Fifty-three percent of Americans say they disapprove of President Donald Trump’s handling of immigration, according to a Washington Post-ABC News-Ipsos poll this month. In February, 48 percent said they disapproved and 50 percent approved.

item.title: Trump’s approval ratings. Pete Hegseth. Pope’s funeral. Measles warning. College pact. NFL draft. Cicada invasion. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump tells Justice Dept to probe Democrats’ core fundraising platform
item.description: The president’s directive to his attorney general to investigate fundraising infrastructure, such as ActBlue, escalates his efforts to target political opponents — in this case, the central machinery of the opposition party.

item.title: Titans pick quarterback Cam Ward, Jaguars take Heisman Trophy winner Travis Hunter to start NFL draft. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The NFL's annual draft is underway in Green Bay, Wisconsin, with the Jaguars making an early splash by trading up to No. 2 to take Hunter. All 32 teams began the day with a first-round pick, something that had never happened in the NFL's modern era, according to the league.

item.title: The top donors to Trump’s $239 million inauguration fund include more than a dozen administration nominees
item.description: President Donald Trump raised a record sum for his 2025 inauguration celebrations, propelled by contributions from corporations and ultra-wealthy individuals. The donors who gave at least $1 million to the fund include crypto companies and a poultry giant.

item.title: Federal judge orders Trump administration to return second migrant sent to megaprison in El Salvador
item.description: U.S. District Judge Stephanie Gallagher in Maryland ruled Wednesday that the man should be returned because he was deported despite being part of a class action settlement that should have protected him from removal. The case marks the second time a federal judge has ordered the Trump administration to return a migrant sent to El Salvador’s Terrorism Confinement Center.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Forceful friend invites herself to all your plans
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Forceful friend invites herself to all your plans

item.title: U.S. could face millions of measles cases over the next 25 years if vaccination rates drop 10 percent, according to new research
item.description: At current state vaccination rates, measles could become commonplace in the U.S. with hundreds of thousands of cases over the same period, according to results from a model published Thursday in the medical journal JAMA.

item.title: Elon Musk had the government in his grasp. Then it unraveled as he clashed with Trump’s Cabinet.
item.description: A showdown last week with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent was the billionaire’s latest confrontation with a top Trump appointee in a controversial three-month stint as head of the U.S. DOGE Service. But Musk sparred with other secretaries and aides well before he announced he would soon head back to Tesla.

item.title: The likely top pick in the NFL draft in today‘s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Trump aides consider opening up at least six national monuments for mining, oil drilling
item.description: Trump officials are analyzing whether to scale back the extent of national monuments spanning millions of acres out West, according to two people familiar with the matter and an internal Interior Department document. Redrawing the boundaries would set up a potential legal battle pitting pro-development conservatives against environmentalists and tribes.

item.title: Pete Hegseth. Elon Musk blowup. Russian strikes. Shrinking monuments. Wildfire smoke. NFL draft. Shakespeare’s wife. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had Signal chat app installed on a computer in his Pentagon office
item.description: Hegseth directed the installation of Signal, a commercially available messaging platform, on a desktop computer, said three people familiar with the matter, illustrating the extent to which he has integrated use of the unclassified communications tool with the highly secure systems the U.S. government relies on to safeguard military plans and other sensitive information. The move was intended to circumvent a lack of cellphone service in much of the Pentagon and enable easier communication with the White House and other Trump officials, these people said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.

item.title: Elon Musk’s fury over a Tesla Autopilot crash investigation foreshadowed his war on Washington
item.description: “Hubris Maximus: The Shattering of Elon Musk,” by Washington Post technology reporter Faiz Siddiqui, details the CEO’s abrasive tactics and contempt for regulators charged with overseeing his companies.

item.title: RFK Jr. and the rise of ‘MAHA moms’: Three columnists discuss health in Trump’s America
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s tenure as HHS secretary has been every bit as troubling as many feared.

item.title: Anti-trans posts pass muster under Meta’s new hate-speech rules
item.description: The social media giant's advisory board approves videos containing disparaging remarks about trans people, in a first test of looser content rules introduced in January.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Grandma tired of hearing the grandkids are ‘too busy’
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Grandma tired of hearing the grandkids are ‘too busy’

item.title: Dick Durbin, Senate’s No. 2 Democrat, announces his retirement, saying ‘it’s time to pass the torch’
item.description: The Illinois senator, first elected to the chamber in 1996, said he won’t seek reelection next year, opening up a senior leadership position and a seat in a deep-blue state.

item.title: Live now: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde joins David Ignatius on The ’Ship, The Post’s new leadership series
item.description: Lagarde talks with our Opinions columnist about her stewardship of the ECB at a pivotal moment for the global economic order. Watch live.

item.title: World’s largest bleaching event on record has harmed 84 percent of coral reefs, scientists say
item.description: As sea temperatures rise, coral reefs around the world are losing their color at an unprecedented scale, federal marine scientists announced this week, with 84 percent of reefs exposed to bleaching levels of heat since 2023. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s new assessment comes amid the planet’s fourth global coral bleaching event.

item.title: Top economic advisers urged Trump to back off attacks on Fed chief after stock markets slid, people familiar with the matter say
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick were among officials warning the president of financial market disruption, according to three people.

item.title: A franchise that's ‘long been tied to real-world politics’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Hegseth under pressure. Tesla slump. Trump’s economy. Vaccine poll. Sarah Palin. Tree-friendly cities. Boozy chimps. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.
